sections.content: Property inspection is your protection against hidden problems that could cost tens of thousands. Professional inspectors examine structure, systems, and components, identifying defects and estimating remaining life. This information lets you negotiate repairs, credits, or walk away. Skipping inspection to 'save' $400 is penny-wise, pound-foolish—it's the best $400 you'll ever spend.

sections.title: What Inspectors Examine
items: Structure: Foundation, framing, walls, floors, ceilings for cracks, settling, damage
Roof: Age, condition, remaining life, leaks, flashing, drainage
HVAC: Heating, cooling systems age, efficiency, proper operation
Plumbing: Pipes, water heater, fixtures, water pressure, leaks, drainage
Electrical: Panel capacity, wiring, outlets, code compliance, safety issues
Exterior: Siding, windows, doors, grading, drainage

sections.content: Inspection reports categorize issues by severity. Major defects (foundation cracks, roof failure, electrical hazards) require immediate attention and significant cost. Minor issues (loose handrails, missing outlet covers) are cheap fixes. Use major issues to negotiate; don't nickel-and-dime sellers over minor cosmetic items. Focus negotiation on expensive repairs.

sections.title: Red Flags and Deal Breakers
items: Foundation issues: Cracks, settling, water intrusion (very expensive, $10k-100k+)
Roof failure: Active leaks, past failure date (replacement $8k-25k depending on size)
Electrical hazards: Outdated wiring, insufficient service, fire risks
Plumbing problems: Sewer line issues, polybutylene pipes, galvanized pipes
Water damage: Mold, rot, structural damage from chronic moisture
Unpermitted work: Additions or renovations done without permits create liability

sections.title: Beyond Standard Inspection
items: Sewer scope: Camera inspection of sewer line ($150-300), reveals root intrusion, breaks
Radon testing: Radioactive gas testing in basement areas ($150)
Mold testing: If musty smells or visible mold present ($300-700)
Structural engineer: If inspector notes foundation or structural concerns ($500-1000)
Pest inspection: Termites, carpenter ants, rodents ($75-150)
Pool/spa inspection: If property has pool, specialized inspection needed

sections.content: Attend the inspection. Walk through with inspector, ask questions, learn about property. This education helps you maintain property later and understand what to monitor. Take photos of important systems, write down model numbers and ages. This information is invaluable for future maintenance and tenant questions.

sections.title: Post-Inspection Negotiation
items: Request major repairs: Ask seller to fix significant issues before closing
Request credits: Negotiate closing cost credits to handle repairs yourself
Price reduction: Lower purchase price to account for needed repairs
Walk away: If issues too severe or seller won't negotiate, exercise contingency
As-is decision: Accept property condition, factor repair costs into investment analysis
Don't sweat small stuff: Focus on major issues, not cosmetic minor items

quiz.question: What's a red flag that might be a deal breaker?
options: Major foundation issues or active roof leaks
quiz.explanation: Major foundation issues and roof failures are expensive ($10k-100k) and can be deal breakers. Cosmetic issues are minor and expected.

quiz.question: Should you attend the property inspection?
options: Yes, learn about the property and ask questions
quiz.explanation: Always attend inspections. You'll learn about the property, understand maintenance needs, and can ask inspector questions in real-time.

sections.content: Cash flow is king in real estate investing. Positive cash flow (income exceeds expenses) creates monthly passive income and protects against vacancies. Negative cash flow drains your finances and turns 'investment' into liability. Accurate cash flow analysis prevents financial disasters. Optimistic assumptions about expenses have bankrupted countless investors—be conservative.

sections.title: Income Components
items: Rental income: Primary source, verify with actual comparable rentals
Other income: Laundry, parking, storage, pet fees (don't overestimate these)
Vacancy factor: Reduce gross income by 5-10% for turnover and vacancy
Reality check: Don't use seller's 'market rent' claims, verify independently
Seasonal factors: Tourist areas have occupancy fluctuations
Rent growth: Conservative 2-3% annual increase is reasonable

sections.content: Example calculation: $2,000 gross monthly rent × 95% occupancy (5% vacancy) = $1,900 monthly income = $22,800 annually. This is your actual income for analysis, not the theoretical $24,000 if perpetually occupied. Always account for vacancy in projections.

sections.title: Operating Expenses
items: Property taxes: Actual amount, check if homestead exemption will be removed
Insurance: Landlord policy, typically 25% more than homeowner policy
Property management: 8-10% of gross rent if hiring manager
Maintenance: 5-10% of rent annually for ongoing repairs
CapEx reserves: 5-10% of rent for major replacements (roof, HVAC, appliances)
Utilities: Water, sewer, trash if landlord pays
HOA fees: If applicable, don't forget these!
Pest control: $30-50 monthly if providing service

sections.title: Cash Flow Calculation
items: 1. Gross rental income: $2,000/month
3. Operating expenses (50% rule): -$950
4. Net Operating Income: $950
5. Mortgage payment: -$800 (principal + interest)
6. Monthly cash flow: $150
Annual cash flow: $150 × 12 = $1,800

sections.content: The 50% rule (operating expenses ≈ 50% of gross rent) is remarkably accurate across most properties. Some markets have higher taxes/insurance (55-60%), others lower (45%). Track your actual expenses to refine estimates. New investors often underestimate expenses by 30-50%, leading to negative cash flow surprises.

sections.title: Return Calculations
items: Cash-on-cash return: Annual cash flow ÷ total cash invested
Example: $1,800 annual cash flow ÷ $45,000 invested = 4% cash-on-cash
Cap rate: NOI ÷ purchase price (measures property performance regardless of financing)
Total return: Cash flow + appreciation + loan paydown (use 8-10% appreciation is optimistic)
Conservative target: 8-12% cash-on-cash return minimum
Remember: Returns improve over time as rents rise and mortgage balance decreases

sections.title: Analysis Mistakes
items: Optimistic rents: Using peak rents or seller's claims instead of verified comps
Underestimating expenses: Forgetting categories or using too-low estimates
No vacancy factor: Assuming 100% occupancy year-round
No CapEx reserves: Not budgeting for roof, HVAC, appliance replacements
Appreciation assumptions: Counting on 5%+ appreciation to make deal work
Ignoring time value: Not accounting for hours spent managing property

quiz.question: What does the 50% rule estimate?
options: Operating expenses equal approximately 50% of gross rent
quiz.explanation: The 50% rule estimates operating expenses (taxes, insurance, maintenance, vacancies, management) typically equal about 50% of gross rental income.

quiz.question: What's a conservative vacancy factor to use?
quiz.explanation: Use 5-10% vacancy factor to account for tenant turnover, vacancies between tenants, and occasional bad tenants requiring eviction.

sections.content: Comparable sales (comps) analysis determines if property is fairly priced. By comparing recent sales of similar properties in the same area, you establish market value. This prevents overpaying and helps spot genuine deals. Appraisers use this method, and so should you before making offers. Markets move fast—analyze comps for every property you're considering.

sections.title: Finding Comparable Sales
items: Location: Within 0.5 miles ideally, 1 mile maximum (same neighborhood)
Property type: Same type (single-family to single-family, not SFH to condo)
Size: Within 15-20% of subject property square footage
Beds/baths: Same bed/bath count (3/2 to 3/2, not 2/1)
Age/condition: Similar age and condition level
Sold recently: Last 3-6 months, older sales less relevant in moving markets

sections.content: Use Zillow, Redfin, Realtor.com to find recent sales. Your agent can provide MLS data with more details. Analyze minimum 3 comps, ideally 5-7. More data points provide better accuracy. If you can't find good comps (rural area, unique property), analysis is harder—proceed with extra caution.

sections.title: Adjustment Factors
items: Square footage: Adjust $50-150 per sqft difference depending on market
Bedrooms/bathrooms: Additional bed worth $5k-15k, bath $3k-10k
Garage: Attached garage adds $5k-20k depending on market
Condition: Outdated/distressed properties worth 10-20% less
Lot size: Larger lots worth more in suburban/rural areas
Updates: Recent renovations (kitchen, bath, floors) add significant value

sections.title: Analysis Example
items: Subject property: 3 bed, 2 bath, 1,500 sqft, needs updates
Comp 1: 3/2, 1,500 sqft, updated, sold $250k (adjust -$15k for condition) = $235k
Comp 2: 3/2, 1,600 sqft, similar condition, sold $245k (adjust -$5k for size) = $240k
Comp 3: 3/2, 1,400 sqft, similar condition, sold $225k (adjust +$5k for size) = $230k
Average adjusted value: ($235k + $240k + $230k) ÷ 3 = $235k
Conclusion: Subject property worth approximately $235k

sections.content: Rental comps work similarly. Find 3-5 properties currently listed for rent or recently rented in same area. Adjust for differences in size, condition, amenities. Verify with landlords if possible—asking rents don't always equal actual leasing prices. Conservative rental estimates prevent cash flow disasters.

sections.title: Comps Analysis Mistakes
items: Cherry-picking comps: Only using sales that support your desired price
Too broad area: Using comps from different neighborhoods with different values
Old sales data: Using 12+ month old sales in changing markets
No adjustments: Treating 1,200 sqft and 1,800 sqft houses as equal
Listing prices: Using active listings instead of actual closed sales
Ignoring trends: Not recognizing if market is rising, flat, or falling

quiz.question: What makes a good comparable sale?
options: Any property in the same city
Similar property within 1 mile, sold in last 3-6 months, same beds/baths
quiz.explanation: Good comps are similar properties (size, beds/baths, condition) within 1 mile that sold recently (3-6 months).

quiz.question: Should you make adjustments when comparing properties?
options: Yes, adjust for size, condition, features differences
Only if properties are very different
quiz.explanation: Always adjust comp values for differences in square footage, condition, bedrooms, bathrooms, and features to estimate accurate market value.

sections.content: Value-add investing means buying properties below market value, making improvements, and either refinancing or selling at higher value. This strategy builds equity quickly and forces appreciation rather than waiting for market appreciation. The BRRRR method (Buy, Rehab, Rent, Refinance, Repeat) uses value-add to recycle capital into multiple properties with minimal money left in deals.

sections.title: Types of Value-Add Properties
items: Cosmetic distress: Outdated but structurally sound, needs paint, flooring, fixtures
Deferred maintenance: Systems work but aged, need HVAC, roof, or appliance replacement
Functional obsolescence: Poor layout, can add bedroom/bath, improve flow
Mismanaged: Under-market rents, can raise to market after improvements
Motivated sellers: Divorce, estate, financial distress create discount opportunities
Hidden potential: Basement finish, garage conversion, ADU addition

sections.content: The 70% rule for flippers: Pay no more than 70% of ARV (after repair value) minus repair costs. Investment example: ARV = $200k, repairs = $30k, maximum price = ($200k × 70%) - $30k = $110k. This leaves room for profit, holding costs, and unexpected expenses. Conservative investors use 65% in competitive markets.

sections.title: High-ROI Improvements
items: Kitchen update: Paint cabinets, new hardware, countertops, backsplash ($3k-8k) adds $10k-20k value
Bathroom refresh: New vanity, toilet, fixtures, tile surround ($2k-5k) adds $8k-15k value
Flooring: Luxury vinyl plank throughout ($3k-6k) transforms appearance
Paint: Interior and exterior fresh paint ($2k-5k) makes massive visual impact
Curb appeal: Landscaping, front door, mailbox ($1k-2k) creates strong first impression
Light fixtures and hardware: Update throughout ($500-1k) modernizes feel

sections.title: Low-ROI Improvements (Avoid)
items: High-end finishes: Granite/quartz may not return cost in middle-class rentals
Custom features: Built-ins, unique elements don't appeal to all buyers/renters
Over-improving for neighborhood: Putting $50k kitchen in $150k house
Major additions: Room additions rarely return full cost
Landscaping overkill: Elaborate landscapes require maintenance, tenants won't maintain
Pool installation: Pools are divisive, limit buyer pool, high maintenance

sections.content: Scope creep kills value-add deals. Set renovation budget before buying, stick to it. Adding 'just one more thing' repeatedly turns profitable projects into money pits. Have fixed-price contracts with contractors or fixed scope if doing work yourself. Time is money—every extra month is lost rent and holding costs.

sections.title: BRRRR Method
items: Buy: Purchase distressed property, often with cash or hard money loan
Rehab: Renovate to add value, increase rental rates
Rent: Place quality tenant at market-rate rent
Refinance: Get conventional mortgage at 75-80% of new appraised value
Repeat: Pull most/all capital out, reinvest in next property
Result: Build portfolio rapidly with same capital recycled repeatedly

sections.title: Value-Add Mistakes
items: Underestimating repairs: Not getting accurate contractor bids before buying
No contingency: Failing to budget 20% extra for unexpected issues
Wrong improvements: Doing what you like instead of what market values
DIY everything: Trying to save money doing work you're not skilled at
No permits: Unpermitted work creates problems at sale or refinance
Scope creep: Adding improvements beyond original budget

quiz.question: What is the 70% rule?
options: Pay no more than 70% of ARV minus repair costs
Spend 70% of budget on property, 30% on repairs
quiz.explanation: The 70% rule states maximum purchase price = 70% of after-repair value minus repair costs, leaving room for profit and contingencies.

quiz.question: What's the highest-ROI improvement?
quiz.explanation: Cosmetic improvements like paint, flooring, and kitchen/bath updates provide highest ROI in rental properties by dramatically improving appearance affordably.

sections.content: Due diligence is your comprehensive investigation before finalizing a purchase. This is when you verify everything about the property, financials, legal status, and market position. Missing critical items during due diligence leads to expensive surprises. Methodical investors use checklists to ensure nothing is overlooked. Every hour spent on due diligence prevents thousands in losses.

sections.title: Physical Property Due Diligence
items: Professional inspection: Structure, systems, major components
Specialized inspections: Sewer, radon, mold, termites, pool as needed
Roof age and condition: Verify remaining life, get contractor estimate if concerns
HVAC systems: Age, operation, efficiency, maintenance records
Water heater: Age (typical life 10-12 years), capacity for property
Appliances: Age and condition of any included appliances
Windows and doors: Condition, age, insulation quality
Foundation and drainage: Cracks, settling, water intrusion, grading

sections.title: Financial Due Diligence
items: Verify rental income: Get lease agreements, verify rent amounts and terms
Review expenses: Request 2 years tax returns, utility bills, maintenance records
Property tax amount: Verify with county, check if homestead exemption will be removed
Insurance quotes: Get actual quotes, don't trust seller estimates
HOA documents: Fees, special assessments, financial health of HOA
Utility costs: If landlord pays any utilities, get historical usage
Deferred maintenance: Estimate cost of needed repairs and replacements

sections.title: Legal and Title Due Diligence
items: Title search: Verify clean title, no liens or claims
Survey: Confirm boundaries, easements, encroachments
Zoning verification: Confirm legal use, check for violations
Permit history: Verify major work was permitted properly
Code violations: Check with city for any open violations
Rent control/regulations: Verify local landlord-tenant laws
Insurance claims history: CLUE report shows property claim history

sections.title: Market Due Diligence
items: Rental comps: Verify rent competitive and achievable
Sales comps: Confirm purchase price reasonable
Occupancy rates: Check market vacancy rates
Days on market: Understand if property or area has absorption issues
Neighborhood visit: Drive area multiple times, day and night
Future development: Research planned projects that might impact value

sections.content: During due diligence period (typically 7-14 days), you can walk away and get earnest money back. Use this time fully—schedule inspection immediately upon going under contract. Don't waste days of contingency period. Get quotes from contractors for any needed work. Every deadline missed reduces your protection.

sections.title: Red Flags to Walk Away
items: Major structural issues: Foundation failure, severe settling, structural damage
Title problems: Liens, claims, or ownership disputes that can't be cleared
Illegal additions: Unpermitted major work that can't be retroactively permitted
Severe environmental issues: Mold throughout, lead paint, asbestos, contaminated soil
Neighborhood decline: Significant crime, abandonment, declining values
Seller misrepresentations: Caught lying about material facts
Numbers don't work: After real due diligence, cash flow is negative

quiz.question: How long is typical due diligence period?
quiz.explanation: Typical due diligence periods are 7-14 days, during which you can walk away and recover earnest money if inspection reveals problems.

quiz.question: What should you do if major structural issues are discovered?
options: Negotiate repair or price reduction, or walk away
Ignore it and hope for best
quiz.explanation: Major issues discovered during due diligence should be negotiated (repairs/credits) or you should exercise contingency and walk away.
